To the Editor:

To the Editor:

Re Mike Deak's article of last week "Council Is
No Big Stew," I have no quarrel with the
News-Letter's attempt to point out the inadequacies
of the Student Council But often times, and in the
case of Mike Deak's article, the News-Letter
oversteps the boundaries of good journalism in its
reporting" of the Student Council.
A large part of Mr Deak's article deals with
petty, jejeune (sic) remarks concerning certain
individuals These types of remarks reflect Mr.
Deak's own personal biases, and make the writer, in
my mind, a more ridiculous and pathetic character
than even myself The article is so crammed with
bitter. defamatory (sic), unjust, .and unwarranted
statements that it completely loses all journalistic
merit Mr Deak even concedes in the article his lack
of objectivity. Subjective journalism of this type
should be confined to the editorial page.
Hopkins students need to be better informed as
to how the student political clique is running its
affairs, and the merit of constant vigilance and
constructive criticism by the News-Letter and all
students cannot be overemphasized. The
News-Letter is to be commended for the times (as in
the Coonskin incident last year) when it has tried to
accomplish this task.
But articles such as "The Council Is No Big Stew"
are a waste of the paper they are printed on, and
only serve as an outlet for the frustrations of their
writers.

Reviewing the Pfeffer Case
What is Hopkins' purpose?
BY RANDY RANDAZZO
During the early part of last semester Associate
Professor Richard M. Pfeffer was denied a tenured
professorship by the Political Science Department (PSD).
Dr. Pfeffer appealed to the Academic Council (AC) for
the formation of an adhoccommittee which would solicit
evaluative letters. from experts in his field. His request for
such a committee was strongly supported by students past
and present (a petition was submitted with 400 student
names), professors (many of which are department
chairmen and former members of the AC), experts in
Asian Studies (including John S. Service, Moss Roberts,
and Noam Chomsky)and other members of the Baltimore
Community including Michael J. Kelly (Dean of the Univ.
of Maryland Law School) and Parren J. Mitchell (U.S.
Congressmen).
During last semester the AC considered the case and
heard the arguments presented by the PSD why Dr.
Pfeffer was not granted tenure. Dr. Robert Tucker,
Chairman of the PSD, explained in detail the
department's ostensible motivation for their decision.
Exactly what Dr. Tucker said at the AC meeting is, of
course, unknown since the proceedings are secret and
information of this nature is deleted from the AC
minutes. In mid-May the AC voted not to form the ad hoc
committee which would have given Dr. Pfeffer a chance
for outside review.
Right now there are three probably explanations for
the PSD's decision. It is either the quality, the quantity,
or the nature of Dr. Pfeffer's scholarship, or any
permutation there of. There is also a fourth possible
reason, which is his teaching ability.
Before anything else is said, it must be pointed out that
the book manuscript which was at the center of the
Pfeffer case was just that, a manuscript. The title of the
manuscript is Working For Capitalism. It was at the time
of the tenure procedures unfinished, unpublished, but
accepted for publication by two reputable presses.
Nevertheless, the ms did not then satisfy Dr. Pfeffer's own
standard of scholarship.
In speaking with members of the AC time after time I
heard that the quality of Dr. Pfeffer's ms was the real
problem. I asked AC members if they had read the rps and
each of them said no, except for one who had read it and
said "it was very good and definitely merited the
formation of an ad hoc committee." As far as I know the
AC member who liked the ms is the only AC member
who read it. When AC members were asked how they
knew the ms was of low quality without reading it, they
said "they were told so by the PSD and they believed
their evaluation." It's as if the PSD words were gospel.
Two questions emerge: Is the PSD's decision really a

A dazzling exhibition of fifty seven cut-outs by Henri
Matisse is on display at the National Gallery in
Washington, D.C. until October 23. The cut-outs were
created by cutting a variety of shapes from large sheets of
paper painted with opaque water-colors. Matisse viewed
the cut-out as "the simplest and most direct way to
express myself." He felt that they linked "drawing and
color in a single movement."
First using this mode in planning the murals for the
Barnes Foundation in Merion, Pennsylvania in the 1930s,
Matisse continu9d to work with cut-outs until his death in
1954. While working on his book, Jazz, from 1943 to
1947, Matisse returned to the cut-out method. Cut-puts
were also employed in designing robes, windows and
other items for the Chapel of St. Paul de Vence, which
Matisse created in celebration of his recovery from a
serious illness.
Matisse was influenced both by Eastern and tropical
motifs. His suite at the Regina hotel in Nice was
festooned with textiles, ceramics, screens, and flowers;
the colors and forms of the Mediterranean and Nice came
through his window as well, Photographs of Matisse's
studio can be seen throughout the exhibition.
The earliest cut-out in the show,La Danse, executed in
1938, recalls the large painting pf a circle of dancers at
the Museum of Modern Art. However, the colors are
darker than those in the later canvases.
The largL pieces are spectacular homages to color and
light. Polynesie, le Ciel (Polynesia, the Sky), of 1946,is a
light blue and lavender checkerboard ornamented by a
crenalated edge and white shapes. Grand Decoration aux
Masques (1953) depjcts two masks ,on either side of a
divider and is enclosed between two columns at either end
of the canvas. Flowers are scattered about in brilliant
...profusion.

Composition Croix Rouge .and Composition Fond Vert,
both of 1947, arc abstractions that convey Mediterranean
influence. In Croix Rouge, the coloring consists of an
intense red cross filled in with blue and black on a red
background and white field; the whole is somewhat
reminiscent of the chasubles done for the chapel at

Vence. Composition Fond Vert displays many of the
tendencies of the Mediterranean motif, with its
suggestions of seaweeds and ferns.
The later cut-outs are largely blue and white and deal
with the female form. La Piscine, a border made to
surround a room, is perhaps the most monumental of
these works. The figures are very sensual and reveal a
greater mastery as the years progress. They are a
testimony to the versatility and force of the colors.
Perhaps the crowning achievement of Matisse's career
was the chapel he designed at Vence. The stained glass for
the chapel is represented at the show by Tree of Life
(1949). The cut-outs, now housed at the Vatican, depict
both a tree and a leaf motif. Matisse also designed
chasubles to be worn by the celebrants during the Mass;
those at the show are red with black and yellow crosses.
The installation is a vital part of an exhibit, and
particularly so in the Matisse show, as the works - clearly
superb in any setting - should be displayed to their best
advantage. The signs at the show are spectacular in blue
and white, the colors of the Midi of Matisse's world, as is
the green of the plants.
•The room size is altered tc the scale of the works
displayed. The beige walls and smaller rooms constructed
within the building's structure create a smaller space,
matching the scale of the early works and allowing them
to explode within the smaller space. The larger works are
given the full benefit of high ceilings and separate rooms,
as is the case with ivegr!sse and Grande Decoration aux
Masques, which share a large room. There are long
corridors and extended paths of vision so that the viewer
is able to stand back and examine a particularly
compelling work.
The treatment of works is altered, however, when the
need arises. The blue and white cut-outs, for example, are
treated differently. More intimate and personal works,
with the human figure as their subject, are in rooms which
are once again smaller; the resulting intimacy is
eightened by carpeting and tawny wall-coloring. The
tained glass from Vence is installed in a sunken white
oom while a white baseboard rises in front of the works.

Statements by Matisse describing his work with the

exhibition. Matisse noted that "colors have a beauty of
their own which must be preserved, as one strives to
preserve the tonal quality in music." The show at the
National Gallery bears witness to the success of his
endeavor., it pays homage to Matisse's peat and joyous
spirit and his brilliant works.

Wargames.
The word conjures images in most people's minds of
warmongerish military -officers moving toy soldiers and
model tanks with long sticks. To those in the armed
services, the word might mean being shot at with blanks
and crawling through mud or going through drills for no
appreciable reason. The wargames here, however, are none
of the above.
Society today rejects war as immoral, while adults
frown upon games as childish and a waste or time. Hence,
the combination of the two makes a wargamer feel
somewhat socially unacceptable.("A wargamer? What are
you, some kind of Nazi?") Yet wargaming is an honored
and venerabll pastime, starting back in 700 AD with the
popularization of chess, or even further back in history
when one considers the ancient game of Go.
What are wargames, who makes them, and who plays
them? Furthermore, what significance do they have in our
society?

Many people are familiar with such popular games as
Risk or Stratego. Yet companies such as Milton Bradley
oiParkerBrothers are not responsible for making games for
a hobby which is reputedly the fastest growing hobby in
the United States today. One of the largest, if not the
largest of the companies that make simulations is the
Avalon Hill Company right here in Baltimore. Another is
Simulations Publications Incorporated in New York.
There are more situated in Illinois, Arizona, California,
etc., All these companies produce games at regular
intervals throughout the year, and these titles are then
sold to the public as any book would be.
Who is the public? Warmongers? Militarists? Red necks
or Hawks?
Gamers are normal people who enjoy an occasional
different type of entertainment. Unlike most hobbies,
however, gaming is not a solitary occupation and hence
many clubs have sprouted up in the past decade. The JHU
Historical Simulations Society is a group on campus
which meets every Saturday morning at ten o'clock in
Maryland 204 to relax, have some fun, play a game or
two, and, in general, get to know each other better.
Interest Group Baltimore is the citywide organization
working in conjunction with Avalon Hill.
Wargames, boardgames, or miniature battles offer a
chance for a person to compete and yet unwind at the
same time. In today's pressure-cooker world, it seems odd
that two or more adults should sit down and move
cardboard pieces around for a couple of hours on a
colored piece of paper, and yet thousands of garners
thoroughly enjoy themselves at every club meeting or
whenever they get a chance to play. These are adult games
and not childrens', and there is a difference.

0
Wargames, or "Historical Simulations" as they are so
0
cleverly renamed, attempt to recreate history and, in
.
particular, historical battles, through the use of a game
system. A game system usually means a board, pieces, and
,
rules. As a historian might wish to know about the battle
of Waterloo by reading a book on that subject, so may a
historian learn about the battle by playing a game of
Waterloo. As subject topics for books on history are ambrai
•
unlimited,so are the number of topics for games.
If a person knows little about the European Theater of
World War Two, what better way to gain quick and
incisive knowledge than by playing a game of Third Reich
Or, if one prefers biblical stories, there's
or WWII?
always a game of Ancient Conquest to be played. In
general, wargames are recreational ways of learning
history.
However, not all wargames deal with war. A
"Classroom" game, that is, one which is used as a teaching
device in many college and high school classes, often
simulates business, political or ecological situations. I
Origins of WWII, as an example, deals with the critical
f
pre-war years of 1934 to 1939, when Hitler and Nazi
Germany achieved international prominence and the
events were set in motion for the disasterous conflict to
follow. A teacher can then explain to his class why
Chamberlain failed to stop Hitler in the political battles at
Munich.
Perhaps, then, historical simulation is not a bad term
for such games after all. Many businesses actually train
key executives with economic simulations. But who
designs these games, and who prints them?

To the beginner, wargames seem very complex. In an
attempt to initiate those unsuspecting customers, certain
companies will purposely publish "beginning" games or
simple style games. Some companies will print
"complexity scales" on their game covers; make no
mistake, some of them are very complex. But that's what
the Historical Simulations Society is for, mainly, to
initiate the uninitiated. Once• a person is iiied to the idea
of games that require thought, imagination, patience, and
a little luck, then he is a true gamer and will never lose the
appreciation for games that he never had.
For some hard facts about gaming, one should know
that it started commercially in 1959 in Baltimore with
Avalon Hill, and now can boast a following of as many as
fifty to seventy five thousand. An interesting note about
the composition of the members is that ninety five
percent of them are male.(While this is understandable in
the light of womens' roles as they have been seen in the
past, it is the author's personal hope that more females
will get interested in gaming.)
So the next time a person says he plays wargames,
don't shy away from him;instead, investigate. If you see a
group playing fantasy role-playing games in the Snack Bar
or Rathskellar, ask them what it's all about. If you prefer,
contact me and I'll be glad to tell you more, but either
way check out a great new way to have fun and learn.

Frederik Prausnitz, with an international reputation as

the distinction of having won the AmericarBruckner

We proceed, with scattered hellds and waves. "You
realize this has all been set up by the publicity
department. and when we get to the end of the street, a
policeman will come up and arrest me, and then you'll
have no interview." He laughs, and one finds it difficult to
coalesce the image of the stereotypical German
conductor, all furrowed brows and intense frowns, with
the self-assured humor that propels thes conversation.
As the interview finally gets underway, Prausnitz insists
that, "I'm going to be asking more questions of you than
you'll ask me. I want to find out what's what with Johns
Hopkins." But first things first, and he explains how it is
that he puts the programs together.
"Well, you see, we have a real advantage over another
orchestra, like the Baltimore Symphony. Because they
have only a certain number of services they can do in a
week, be it rehearsals, concerts, benefits or whatever,
there's only so much they can do in rehearsal. We will
have more time, and I'm planning to do some really
different things in rehearsal."
•
Because the Peabody Orchestra is a learning experience
in addition to being a concert organisation, there seems to
be more involved than just playing the music, in fact,
more than just learning the basic repertory.
"Some people say, 'Why don't you just start them off
with something simple, like a Haydyn Symphony?' Why,I
couldn't think of anything more difficult! There are such
matters as getting the right sound. "The orchestras then
were small, yes, but with this particular symphony
(Symphony 86, to be performed at the Orchestra's
opening concert), one of the 'Paris' Symphonies, there
were forty violins. Even then, though, the instruments

were different, and so maybe forty of their violins equal
twenty of ours, we don't know."
"But it's not just a question of scaling down the
orchestra. There is a chord progression in that Symphony
which was very shocking in its day. Of course, today we
don't find it at all unusual. So you must tell the orchestra,
'This is supposed to be a shock.'"
Perhaps most startling among his ideas is the firm
conviction that the new music, particularly the new
American music, must be played. "In Germany, we would
play a lot of German music, some of which wouldn't be
played over here. Over here, a lot of German music gets
played (some of which wouldn't be played over there),
butnot much American music."
If only because the students are living now, it should be

And, says Prausnitz, it is going to be the repertoire a

In a professional orchestra, the conductor expects the
musicians to be able to play the new music. They don't
want to have to g9 over it (the new techniques) with the
orchestra."
Of course, not every musician is as receptive to the new
music as Pausnitz. In fact, quite a few young musicians
would prefer to ignore it. "Students tend to be very
conservative, and you really can't blame them. They have
their whole life ahead of them; why should they want to
take chances?" He smiles. "At my age, I can. afford to..."
Coming to Baltimore from London, afrer.a career that
put him in almost every major city in Europe, Prausnitz is
still somewhat amazed by how much there is in
Baltimore. "I had heard, of course, about the Baltimore

Symphony, Hopkins, and Peabody, but I had no idea
there was this mucli! Why the Walters alone....I was at the
Mechanic last night, to see Golda Baltimore,is really very
lucky to have the theatre, and even with its problems, it's
in as good a shape as most theatres. But to get first run
performances of such quality plays... "There are places I
haven't been to yet, but it's not because I'm not
interested', it's just that there's so much!" This helps the
artistic climate in Baltimore, and even the Peabody
Orchestra. "If things are good for the theatre, things are
good for music."

Hopkins Jolted By Crusaders
After opening
their season on an unimpressive
note, the Blue Jay football squad
will meet tough division rival
Muhlenberg
tomorrow on
Homewood field to begin their •
hase of the conference title.
A week earlier the Jays were
jolted by the Crusaders of
Susquehanna University in
Selinsgrove, Pennsylvania, by the
count of 20-12.
Offensively, the Blue Jays
scored first when, in the opening
quarter senior quarterback Bob
DeSimone plunged into the
endzone from one yard out. The
conversion kick was missed by
junior Steve Love and the Jays
led 6-0. They took their lead into
the locker room at the half, but
found themselves faced with a

more aggressive Susquehanna
team in the second half.
Back up Crusader quarterback
Mike Keating led a Susquehanna
drive off the opening kickoff that
led to his eventual five yard
score. When he hit receiver Mike
Rush for the two point
conversion, the Crusaders were in
the lead.
DeSimone, who led a Jay
offense that collected 112 net
yards, 36 through the air, put the
Blue Jays back on top with a
three yard run late in the third
quarter. Again the conversion
was blown, this time a two point
attempt, and the score stood at
12-8.
Top offensive back for the
Crusaders, Paul O'Neill spelled
the difference in the fourth

quarter as he tallied 'two
touchdowns, one from fourteen
yards out and the other from
four yards. This awesome runner
busted through the Blue Jay
defensive line for 177 yards in 33
carries. The entire Susquehanna
offense picked up a blistering
327 yards on the ground and 89
yards through the air.
"I believe that we gave a good
effort against Susquehanna,"
cited Coach Denny Cox. "Of
course, we made quite a few
technical .mistakes that I plan to
correct this week in practice.
Muhlenberg is a tough team
especially with their strong
quarterback, John Schlecter. We
are in good shape, though, for
this weekend's match."

Reviewing the Pfeffer Case
What is Hopkins' purpose?
BY RANDY RANDAZZO
During the early part of last semester Associate
Professor Richard M. Pfeffer was denied a tenured
professorship by the Political Science Department (PSD).
Dr. Pfeffer appealed to the Academic Council (AC) for
the formation of an adhoccommittee which would solicit
evaluative letters. from experts in his field. His request for
such a committee was strongly supported by students past
and present (a petition was submitted with 400 student
names), professors (many of which are department
chairmen and former members of the AC), experts in
Asian Studies (including John S. Service, Moss Roberts,
and Noam Chomsky)and other members of the Baltimore
Community including Michael J. Kelly (Dean of the Univ.
of Maryland Law School) and Parren J. Mitchell (U.S.
Congressmen).
During last semester the AC considered the case and
heard the arguments presented by the PSD why Dr.
Pfeffer was not granted tenure. Dr. Robert Tucker,
Chairman of the PSD, explained in detail the
department's ostensible motivation for their decision.
Exactly what Dr. Tucker said at the AC meeting is, of
course, unknown since the proceedings are secret and
information of this nature is deleted from the AC
minutes. In mid-May the AC voted not to form the ad hoc
committee which would have given Dr. Pfeffer a chance
for outside review.
Right now there are three probably explanations for
the PSD's decision. It is either the quality, the quantity,
or the nature of Dr. Pfeffer's scholarship, or any
permutation there of. There is also a fourth possible
reason, which is his teaching ability.
Before anything else is said, it must be pointed out that
the book manuscript which was at the center of the
Pfeffer case was just that, a manuscript. The title of the
manuscript is Working For Capitalism. It was at the time
of the tenure procedures unfinished, unpublished, but
accepted for publication by two reputable presses.
Nevertheless, the ms did not then satisfy Dr. Pfeffer's own
standard of scholarship.
In speaking with members of the AC time after time I
heard that the quality of Dr. Pfeffer's ms was the real
problem. I asked AC members if they had read the rps and
each of them said no, except for one who had read it and
said "it was very good and definitely merited the
formation of an ad hoc committee." As far as I know the
AC member who liked the ms is the only AC member
who read it. When AC members were asked how they
knew the ms was of low quality without reading it, they
said "they were told so by the PSD and they believed
their evaluation." It's as if the PSD words were gospel.
Two questions emerge: Is the PSD's decision really a
professional evaluation? And are there any biases inherent
in their decision? At the outset it is safely said that
nobody in the PSD can be considered professionally
competent to evaluate work done on China, Marxism, or
Capitalism. No one writes or teaches in matters even
distantly related to these areas.

As far as biases or subjective feelings being involved in
the department's "professional" decision, members of the
AC that I have spoken to have assured me this is not
possible. I can hardly believe that the AC is naive enough
to believe that these professors did not let their feelings
toward Dr. Pfeffer influence their decision. It is no secret
that Dr. Pfeffer's unconventional ways irked many
members of the PSD and at least several members simply
do not like him. Apparently Pfeffer caused these faculty
members problems and possibly unconsciously they saw a
way to get rid of him and to get an assistant professor for
the department who would operate as a member of 'the
club' and study and teach what he was supposed to.
In summing Up this section, it appears that there is at
least real doubt as to whether the quality of the ins was
evaluated professionally and objectively. Dr. Pfeffer has
spent this past summer revising his ins and it is scheduled
for publication by the prestigious Columbia University
Press, whose reader called it "a very valuable contribution
to the field." One would think that the ms might very
well be good scholarship. The only way to fairly
determine the quality of the ms is for an ad hoc
committee to be formed which would obtain opinions
from experts in Dr. Pfeffer's fields.
• Many people talk about Dr. Pfeffer's ms as if it is the
only piece of work he's done since his last promotion to
associate professor in 1972. Dr. Jack Green of the AC,for
example, gave me the impression that Dr. Pfeffer had
done little else besides the ms since '72. Maybe this is
what most members of the community think, but his
isn't true. Dr. Pfeffer in fact has published nine articles
since his last promotion, five of which could be
considered scholarly even by members of his own
department (see list of publications).
One professor I talked to said "the nine articles he has
written since 1972 should have been enough to warrant
tenure."
In this light it seems that the PSD ignored the quantity
of Dr. Pfeffer's work because such productivity would
seem to demand the convoking of an ad hoc committee if
not tenure itself.
Dr. Richard Cone who has been working on Dr.
Pfeffer's behalf, has concisely described Dr. Pfeffer's
work. He said: "The nature of Dr. Pfeffer's scholarship is
consistent with the nature of his other contributions to
the University: it is activist, provocative, and sometimes
polemical. it is, as well, responsbiel, honest, and
insistently directed at fundamental questions and
concepts of Maoism, Marxism, and Capitalism as pi _aced
in China and in the United States." The nature of Dr.
Pfeffer's,/ ork may well be the real reason why he was
granted tenure. His scholarship is not Political Science as
the PSD sees it. No tenured members of the PSD are
professionally interested in Marxism, Asia, or related
areas. By constrast, an AC member who supported Dr.
Pfeffer said: "Sooner or late people in the U.S. are going
to wake up and realize that there are eight hundred
million people in China and it might be an important
place to study."To a large extent some professors in the
PSD work in an intellectual vacuum. They look at
questions or do research in areas where they know their
colleagues' interests lie. Dr. Pfeffer has stepped outstide

Got your clubs together?

of this cozy little world and is looking at questions 01
larger importance to society. Ile is questioning the very
principles upon which the American political system is
founded. Before we look at questions within the
American political system, Pfeffer demands we ask
questions about the system as a whole.
Pfeffer's case raises the question, of what the
University's purpose is in America. One would think that
the University should look at grand questions as well as
narrower ones. It should be responsive to the needs of
people, not simply as fashions and conventions dictate,
and not as certain small segmented groups of specialists
see them. In view of Dr. Pfeffer's valuable contributions
to the University, the formation of an ad hoc committee
is certainly merited.
It is common knowledge that Dr. Pfeffer is an
excellent teacher. He had been rated by the Student
Course Guide as on of the top ten professors on campus.
He has a unique ability to motivate his students to think
critically and analytically. He trains his students not to
accept anything at face value; he demands thorough
intellectual investigation of all ideas, concepts, and
systems discussed in class. This is a rare class room
experience at Hopkins. Too many professors at
Hopkins are quite content with a less questioning
treatment of any subject matter.
One may wonder whether Dr. Pfeffer's teaching
excellence in fact may not have adversely affected his
tenure proceedings. An AC member speculating on the
PSD's decision said "I felt it was not based on their
hostility to his Marxist viewpoint, but on his popularity
with undergraduates and the Hopkins Community. I felt
their decision was based on jealousy." He goes on to say
"How long will the university ignore undergraduate
education? Someday the university will realize that
Undergraduate education is not of third or fourth
importance." It is quite possible that members of the PSD
dislike Dr. Pfeffer because he is popular.
Relatedly Dr. Richard Cone said "If a professor is a
very good teacher, it is a forgone conclusion he is a bad
scholar in his field. It's hard for faculty members to
imagine that a professor who is an excellent teacher could
posssibly be a leading scholar in his field. How can he do
both? Clearly he must flitter away all his time with
students." Dr. Cone further stated that "Professors often
are frightened away from teaching because they are
challenged by an audience of students and they worry
about their performance." Perhaps this is why the quality
of a professor's teaching is not given effective
consideration during tenure procedures.
In conclusion, after looking at the evidence I think the
past a decision was narrowminded at best. The AC is
responsible for the well being of the whole university and
should look at issues from the point of view of the well
being of the entire Hopkins Community and not from
that of a small part; i.e. the PSD.But the most important
reason why Dr. Pfeffer should get an ad hoc committee is
what David Chesanow (Student Council President) said in
last week's Newsletter: "It is a fundamental tenet of
American and all other civilized systems of jurisprudence
that one is entitled to appeal a court decision which he
deems unjust."

A dazzling exhibition of fifty seven cut-outs by Henri
Matisse is on display at the National Gallery in
Washington, D.C. until October 23. The cut-outs were
created by cutting a variety of shapes from large sheets of
paper painted with opaque water-colors. Matisse viewed
the cut-out as "the simplest and most direct way to
express myself." He felt that they linked "drawing and
color in a single movement."
First using this mode in planning the murals for the
Barnes Foundation in Merion, Pennsylvania in the 1930s,
Matisse continu9d to work with cut-outs until his death in
1954. While working on his book, Jazz, from 1943 to
1947, Matisse returned to the cut-out method. Cut-puts
were also employed in designing robes, windows and
other items for the Chapel of St. Paul de Vence, which
Matisse created in celebration of his recovery from a
serious illness.
Matisse was influenced both by Eastern and tropical
motifs. His suite at the Regina hotel in Nice was
festooned with textiles, ceramics, screens, and flowers;
the colors and forms of the Mediterranean and Nice came
through his window as well, Photographs of Matisse's
studio can be seen throughout the exhibition.
The earliest cut-out in the show,La Danse, executed in
1938, recalls the large painting pf a circle of dancers at
the Museum of Modern Art. However, the colors are
darker than those in the later canvases.
The largL pieces are spectacular homages to color and
light. Polynesie, le Ciel (Polynesia, the Sky), of 1946,is a
light blue and lavender checkerboard ornamented by a
crenalated edge and white shapes. Grand Decoration aux
Masques (1953) depjcts two masks ,on either side of a
divider and is enclosed between two columns at either end
of the canvas. Flowers are scattered about in brilliant
...profusion.

Composition Croix Rouge .and Composition Fond Vert,
both of 1947, arc abstractions that convey Mediterranean
influence. In Croix Rouge, the coloring consists of an
intense red cross filled in with blue and black on a red
background and white field; the whole is somewhat
reminiscent of the chasubles done for the chapel at

Vence. Composition Fond Vert displays many of the
tendencies of the Mediterranean motif, with its
suggestions of seaweeds and ferns.
The later cut-outs are largely blue and white and deal
with the female form. La Piscine, a border made to
surround a room, is perhaps the most monumental of
these works. The figures are very sensual and reveal a
greater mastery as the years progress. They are a
testimony to the versatility and force of the colors.
Perhaps the crowning achievement of Matisse's career
was the chapel he designed at Vence. The stained glass for
the chapel is represented at the show by Tree of Life
(1949). The cut-outs, now housed at the Vatican, depict
both a tree and a leaf motif. Matisse also designed
chasubles to be worn by the celebrants during the Mass;
those at the show are red with black and yellow crosses.
The installation is a vital part of an exhibit, and
particularly so in the Matisse show, as the works - clearly
superb in any setting - should be displayed to their best
advantage. The signs at the show are spectacular in blue
and white, the colors of the Midi of Matisse's world, as is
the green of the plants.
•The room size is altered tc the scale of the works
displayed. The beige walls and smaller rooms constructed
within the building's structure create a smaller space,
matching the scale of the early works and allowing them
to explode within the smaller space. The larger works are
given the full benefit of high ceilings and separate rooms,
as is the case with ivegr!sse and Grande Decoration aux
Masques, which share a large room. There are long
corridors and extended paths of vision so that the viewer
is able to stand back and examine a particularly
compelling work.
The treatment of works is altered, however, when the
need arises. The blue and white cut-outs, for example, are
treated differently. More intimate and personal works,
with the human figure as their subject, are in rooms which
are once again smaller; the resulting intimacy is
eightened by carpeting and tawny wall-coloring. The
tained glass from Vence is installed in a sunken white
oom while a white baseboard rises in front of the works.

Wargames.
The word conjures images in most people's minds of
warmongerish military -officers moving toy soldiers and
model tanks with long sticks. To those in the armed
services, the word might mean being shot at with blanks
and crawling through mud or going through drills for no
appreciable reason. The wargames here, however, are none
of the above.
Society today rejects war as immoral, while adults
frown upon games as childish and a waste or time. Hence,
the combination of the two makes a wargamer feel
somewhat socially unacceptable.("A wargamer? What are
you, some kind of Nazi?") Yet wargaming is an honored
and venerabll pastime, starting back in 700 AD with the
popularization of chess, or even further back in history
when one considers the ancient game of Go.
What are wargames, who makes them, and who plays
them? Furthermore, what significance do they have in our
society?

Many people are familiar with such popular games as
Risk or Stratego. Yet companies such as Milton Bradley
oiParkerBrothers are not responsible for making games for
a hobby which is reputedly the fastest growing hobby in
the United States today. One of the largest, if not the
largest of the companies that make simulations is the
Avalon Hill Company right here in Baltimore. Another is
Simulations Publications Incorporated in New York.
There are more situated in Illinois, Arizona, California,
etc., All these companies produce games at regular
intervals throughout the year, and these titles are then
sold to the public as any book would be.
Who is the public? Warmongers? Militarists? Red necks
or Hawks?
Gamers are normal people who enjoy an occasional
different type of entertainment. Unlike most hobbies,
however, gaming is not a solitary occupation and hence
many clubs have sprouted up in the past decade. The JHU
Historical Simulations Society is a group on campus
which meets every Saturday morning at ten o'clock in
Maryland 204 to relax, have some fun, play a game or
two, and, in general, get to know each other better.
Interest Group Baltimore is the citywide organization
working in conjunction with Avalon Hill.
Wargames, boardgames, or miniature battles offer a
chance for a person to compete and yet unwind at the
same time. In today's pressure-cooker world, it seems odd
that two or more adults should sit down and move
cardboard pieces around for a couple of hours on a
colored piece of paper, and yet thousands of garners
thoroughly enjoy themselves at every club meeting or
whenever they get a chance to play. These are adult games
and not childrens', and there is a difference.

0
Wargames, or "Historical Simulations" as they are so
0
cleverly renamed, attempt to recreate history and, in
.
particular, historical battles, through the use of a game
system. A game system usually means a board, pieces, and
,
rules. As a historian might wish to know about the battle
of Waterloo by reading a book on that subject, so may a
historian learn about the battle by playing a game of
Waterloo. As subject topics for books on history are ambrai
•
unlimited,so are the number of topics for games.
If a person knows little about the European Theater of
World War Two, what better way to gain quick and
incisive knowledge than by playing a game of Third Reich
Or, if one prefers biblical stories, there's
or WWII?
always a game of Ancient Conquest to be played. In
general, wargames are recreational ways of learning
history.
However, not all wargames deal with war. A
"Classroom" game, that is, one which is used as a teaching
device in many college and high school classes, often
simulates business, political or ecological situations. I
Origins of WWII, as an example, deals with the critical
f
pre-war years of 1934 to 1939, when Hitler and Nazi
Germany achieved international prominence and the
events were set in motion for the disasterous conflict to
follow. A teacher can then explain to his class why
Chamberlain failed to stop Hitler in the political battles at
Munich.
Perhaps, then, historical simulation is not a bad term
for such games after all. Many businesses actually train
key executives with economic simulations. But who
designs these games, and who prints them?

To the beginner, wargames seem very complex. In an
attempt to initiate those unsuspecting customers, certain
companies will purposely publish "beginning" games or
simple style games. Some companies will print
"complexity scales" on their game covers; make no
mistake, some of them are very complex. But that's what
the Historical Simulations Society is for, mainly, to
initiate the uninitiated. Once• a person is iiied to the idea
of games that require thought, imagination, patience, and
a little luck, then he is a true gamer and will never lose the
appreciation for games that he never had.
For some hard facts about gaming, one should know
that it started commercially in 1959 in Baltimore with
Avalon Hill, and now can boast a following of as many as
fifty to seventy five thousand. An interesting note about
the composition of the members is that ninety five
percent of them are male.(While this is understandable in
the light of womens' roles as they have been seen in the
past, it is the author's personal hope that more females
will get interested in gaming.)
So the next time a person says he plays wargames,
don't shy away from him;instead, investigate. If you see a
group playing fantasy role-playing games in the Snack Bar
or Rathskellar, ask them what it's all about. If you prefer,
contact me and I'll be glad to tell you more, but either
way check out a great new way to have fun and learn.

Heated arguments and burning
shots kept all eyes focused on
playing action Wednesday night
as the Hopkins soccer -team
defeated Towson State with an
impressive 4-2 victory at
Homewood Field.
In first half action the Blue
Jay's offense launched an
aggressive frontline attack with
three goals scored during the first
twenty minutes of play. Ken
Suesse, junior right winger,
assisted by Bob Teasdall made
the first Blue Jay score with a
fifteen yard shot. This was
followed up tifteeniminutes-later
by junior Teisdall when he fired
a shot past the Towson keeper.
Senior larry McGowan crowned
the Hopkins scoring blitz with a
third goal, which gave Hopkins a
commanding lead.
Towson State, however, did
try to fight back with both a goal
and a referee arguement late in
the first half. One Towson State
defender, unhappy with a foul
called against him for obstructing
a Jay player, spit in the face of
fullback Tom Ball and proceeded
- to skirmish with one of the
referrees, resulting in the player's
ejection. This player suspension
was followed by another early in
the second half when a second
Towson defender was suspended

fromplay
after two referee
warnings. This action put
Hopkins in an excellent position
with a two man advantage on
Towson State which they were
unfortunately unable to
capitalize on.
Barry White of Towson State
tallied a second Towson score
early in the second half which
was later followed by another
Teasdall goal. Bob Teasdall,
junior center, who played
outstanding soccer throughout
the game fired a shot past the
Towson keeper for the goal
which iced the Jay victory.
Excellent defensive play by
Hopkins fullbacks Steve
Galloway and Frank Olszewski
helped contribute to the
overwhelming Towson defeat.
Coach Bob Oliver: had
ambivalent feelings about the
game as a whole. "I was very.
pleased with first half play,
especially the quick advantage
gained by our offensive line;
however, I feel we should have
made more of the last half
situation 'where we had a two
man advantage over Towson."

impressive last Saturday when
they lost to Haverford 2-1 •at
homewood in an important •
divisional matchup.

Hopkins Jolted By Crusaders
After opening
their season on an unimpressive
note, the Blue Jay football squad
will meet tough division rival
Muhlenberg
tomorrow on
Homewood field to begin their •
hase of the conference title.
A week earlier the Jays were
jolted by the Crusaders of
Susquehanna University in
Selinsgrove, Pennsylvania, by the
count of 20-12.
Offensively, the Blue Jays
scored first when, in the opening
quarter senior quarterback Bob
DeSimone plunged into the
endzone from one yard out. The
conversion kick was missed by
junior Steve Love and the Jays
led 6-0. They took their lead into
the locker room at the half, but
found themselves faced with a

more aggressive Susquehanna
team in the second half.
Back up Crusader quarterback
Mike Keating led a Susquehanna
drive off the opening kickoff that
led to his eventual five yard
score. When he hit receiver Mike
Rush for the two point
conversion, the Crusaders were in
the lead.
DeSimone, who led a Jay
offense that collected 112 net
yards, 36 through the air, put the
Blue Jays back on top with a
three yard run late in the third
quarter. Again the conversion
was blown, this time a two point
attempt, and the score stood at
12-8.
Top offensive back for the
Crusaders, Paul O'Neill spelled
the difference in the fourth

quarter as he tallied 'two
touchdowns, one from fourteen
yards out and the other from
four yards. This awesome runner
busted through the Blue Jay
defensive line for 177 yards in 33
carries. The entire Susquehanna
offense picked up a blistering
327 yards on the ground and 89
yards through the air.
"I believe that we gave a good
effort against Susquehanna,"
cited Coach Denny Cox. "Of
course, we made quite a few
technical .mistakes that I plan to
correct this week in practice.
Muhlenberg is a tough team
especially with their strong
quarterback, John Schlecter. We
are in good shape, though, for
this weekend's match."
